thread.title: Great white shark approaches surfer waiting for a wave; video
thread.title_full: Great white shark approaches surfer waiting for a wave; video

title: Great white shark approaches surfer waiting for a wave; video
text:
Great white shark approaches surfer waiting for a wave; video 
  David Strege 
As part of a five-year, $16 million Shark Management Strategy, Australian officials in New South Wales are testing the viability of using drones as spotters for dangerous great white sharks. 
The NSW Department of Primary Industries just released a video showing the various sea creatures captured in aerial footage at Lighthouse Beach in Ballina, an area that has seen seven shark attacks since February 2014, including a fatal one, according to the Gold Coast Bulletin . 
The video includes a juvenile great white shark as it checks out a bodyboarder and surfer; cut to the 2:03 mark for the close encounter: 
The great white shark follows the bodyboarder riding a wave and then spots the surfer sitting on his board waiting for another wave. He doesn’t appear to know the shark is approaching. 
When the surfer starts kicking his right foot in preparation to catch the wave, the sudden movement scares off the great white shark. 
RELATED: Great white shark breaches behind surfer riding wave in amazing photo 
It isn’t clear how the warning system works once a shark is spotted by a drone, or whether those riding waves in this video were made aware of the shark’s presence. But hopefully the system works. 
New South Wales has experienced a sharp increase in shark attacks, prompting officials to try various methods to prevent them. In the past two years, there’s been 27 shark attacks with one fatality.
